description: From Middle English arisen, from Old English ÄrÄ«san (â€œto arise, get up; rise; spring from, originate; spring up, ascendâ€), from Proto-Germanic *uzrÄ«sanÄ… (â€œto rise up, ariseâ€), equivalent to a- +â€ rise. Cognate with Scots arise, aryse (â€œto arise, rise up, come into existenceâ€), Middle Low German errÄ«sen (â€œto stand up, ariseâ€), Old High German irrÄ«san (â€œto rise up, fallâ€), Gothic ğŒ¿ğ‚ğ‚ğŒ´ğŒ¹ğƒğŒ°ğŒ½ (urreisan, â€œto ariseâ€). Eclipsed Middle English sourden, sorden, borrowed from Old French sordre, sourdre (â€œto arise, originate, fly upâ€).

verbs.description: arise (third-person singular simple present arises, present participle arising, simple past arose, past participle arisen)

entries.meaning: To come up from a lower to a higher position.
examples: to arise from a kneeling posture

entries.meaning: To come up from one's bed or place of repose; to get up.
examples: He arose early in the morning.

entries.meaning: To spring up; to come into action, being, or notice; to become operative, sensible, or visible; to begin to act a part; to present itself.
examples: A cloud arose and covered the sun.
